<Summary source="https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/ai-artist-xania-monet-debut-adult-rb-airplay-chart-1236102665/">
# Summary of Article: AI Artist Xania Monet Debuts on Adult R&B Airplay Chart

**Key Facts and Statistics:**

- Xania Monet's song "How Was I Supposed to Know?" debuted at No. 30 on Billboard's Adult R&B Airplay chart (dated Nov. 1, 2025)
- This marks the first known instance of an AI-based artist appearing on a Billboard radio chart
- The song improved 28% in plays for the tracking week of Oct. 17-23 compared to Oct. 10-16
- 15 of the chart-contributing adult R&B radio stations played the song (out of 57 total reporters), according to Mediabase
- The song previously debuted at No. 1 on the R&B Digital Song Sales chart (dated Sept. 20)
- The song started at No. 20 on the Hot R&B Songs chart a week later (Sept. 27)
- Xania Monet is an AI-driven artist created by a poet named Telisha Jones
- The song first gained attention as a viral track on TikTok and other social media platforms

**Named Source Opinions:**

- Romel Murphy (Xania Monet's manager): 
  - States the song "is resonating with the masses"
  - Confirms radio promotion is part of their strategy: "If you had a, let's say, traditional, artist and were a label and marketing executive, radio would be a piece of the promotion strategy"
  - Goal is to "continue to grow, continue to connect and hopefully get to No. 1"
  - Asks observers to "just listen to the songs. Listen to the lyrics. And then make your judgment"

**Other Notable Information:**

- The song and artist have generated both supportive and opposing perspectives
- SZA and Kehlani are among the most prominent opponents (no specific quotes provided)
- Billboard reached out to several radio stations' programming and music directors for comment, but none replied
- The article notes that the Emerging Artists chart has featured several AI-driven acts in recent weeks
- The author characterizes this as indicating "the growing likelihood of AI-driven artists as a major industry transformation"
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://djrobblog.com/archives/23846">
# Summary of Article: "Billboard just blocked the first-ever AI song from the Hot 100"

**Source:** Djrobblog.com  
**Date:** November 20, 2025

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **The Blocked Song:** A track called "I Run" by virtual act HAVEN, created by UK producer Harrison Walker, was expected to debut around position 60 on the Hot 100 based on sales, streams, and radio points (particularly from TikTok virality)
- **Chart Data Reliability:** The prediction came from "a reliable data account with an accuracy rate around 99%"
- **Billboard's Action:** The song did not appear on the Hot 100 chart released November 18, 2025, despite earning sufficient chart points
- **Platform Removals:** Spotify, Apple Music, and other streamers have removed the track, though it remains available on iTunes
- **Vocal Credits Dispute:** Producer Walker claims the vocals are his own, heavily manipulated to sound like a female voice, though the song features a named singer "Kaitlin Aragon"

## AI Songs on Other Billboard Charts:

- At least **six AI acts** have charted on Billboard in "the past few months" (as of November 2025)
- **Xania Monet** (created by Telisha Nikki Jones using Suno) became the first AI act to debut on a Billboard chart with real radio airplay
- **Breaking Rust** hit No. 1 on Country Digital Song Sales chart with "Walk My Walk"
- AI acts have appeared on genre-specific charts including Hot R&B Songs, Country Digital Song Sales, and Hot Gospel Songs

## Opinions and Analysis:

**From the article author (DJROBBLOG):**
- Notes Billboard hasn't issued a formal new rule but appears to have a "philosophical stance: The Hot 100 is meant to track the consumption of real human artists"
- Cites a recent study showing **97% of listeners cannot distinguish AI-generated tracks from traditionally created ones**
- Draws parallel to the 2019 "Old Town Road" removal from Hot Country Songs, which resulted in public backlash and the song becoming the longest-running No. 1 in Hot 100 history

**From Xania Monet's creator (Telisha Nikki Jones):**
- Describes her AI creation as "a fictional artist, dreamed up by a real one, now functioning alongside human performers in the digital space"

## Important Update:

Billboard issued a statement on November 20, 2025 stating that "I Run" was withheld from charts "as a result of the [legal] dispute," though the article notes the specific legal dispute is unclear.

**Note:** This article provides important context about Billboard's current stance on AI-generated music and charts, which is directly relevant to the underlying Metaculus question about whether an AI song will chart in the Hot 100's top 20 before 2027.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Culture/ai-generated-country-song-topping-billboards-country-digital/story?id=127445549">
# Summary of Article: "AI-generated country song tops Billboard chart, makes waves in music world"

## Key Facts and Statistics:
- "Walk my Walk" by Breaking Rust, an AI-generated song, reached No. 1 on Billboard's Country Digital Song Sales chart
- The song has been streamed over 3 million times on Spotify in under a month
- Billboard has acknowledged Breaking Rust is an AI act
- Breaking Rust is one of at least six AI acts to chart in the past few months alone

## Named Source Opinions:
- Kelley L. Carter (senior entertainment reporter) told ABC News:
  - "Ultimately, this feels like an experiment to see just how far something like this can go and what happens in the future and in other disciplines of art as well"
  - "AI artists won't require things that a real human artist will require, and once companies start considering it and looking at bottom lines, I think that's when artists should rightly be concerned about it"

## Additional Context:
- The song has generated mixed reactions from music fans and artists
- Hundreds of TikTok users have posted videos addressing the tune and discussing it in comments
- ABC News attempted to reach Breaking Rust's creator for comment but did not receive a response

## Note on Relevance:
While this article discusses an AI song charting on Billboard's Country Digital Song Sales chart, the original Metaculus question specifically concerns the Billboard Hot 100 chart, which is a different chart. This achievement may be relevant as a potential indicator of AI music's growing presence on Billboard charts generally.
</Summary>

**Will AGI arrive before the worst climate tipping points? -- LessWrong**
The article, published on February 3, 2026, by Maya Farber Brodsky on LessWrong, examines the race between the emergence of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) and the onset of critical climate tipping points. Based on Metaculus predictions, the median forecast for AGI is 2033, with a 25% lower bound of 2028 and a 75% upper bound of 2045. Climate tipping points include the West Antarctica Ice Sheet (WAIS) melt, coral reef collapse, Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) collapse, Amazon dieback, and termination shock from geoengineering. The article argues that while WAIS melt and Amazon dieback are slow processes unfolding over decades to centuries, AMOC collapse could begin as early as 2037 (though this is highly speculative), and termination shock—caused by abrupt cessation of stratospheric aerosol injection—could lead to rapid warming and civilizational risk. The author emphasizes that AGI may arrive faster than climate tipping points, which could shift strategic priorities: if AGI emerges early, it may either accelerate climate solutions or exacerbate emissions through economic growth. However, climate disasters could undermine global cooperation and distract from AI safety. The article concludes that both threats must be considered together, urging climate researchers to integrate AI risks into their agendas and the AI community to account for climate instability. The piece is supported by references to IPCC reports, climate modeling, and prediction markets.

Publish date: February 03, 2026 02:36 AM

**AI Predicted Who Made the 2026 Super Bowl. Can It Pick the Winner?**
On February 2, 2026, four AI chatbots—ChatGPT, Microsoft Copilot, Google Gemini, and Claude—were used to predict outcomes for the 2026 Super Bowl (Super Bowl LX). All four correctly predicted that the Seattle Seahawks and New England Patriots would face off in the championship game. They unanimously forecasted a Seahawks victory by a margin of 27 points, with final scores of either 27-23 or 27-24. The AI systems also agreed on the coin toss outcome: three predicted the Seahawks would win the toss, choose tails, and defer to the Patriots; Gemini predicted the Patriots would win the toss. All four systems predicted Bad Bunny would headline the halftime show, with cameos from Cardi B and J Balvin, and listed specific songs including 'Tití Me Preguntó', 'Me Porto Bonito', 'I Like It', 'Dákiti', 'Baile Inolvidable', 'El Apagón', 'NuevaYol', and 'Yo Perreo Sola'. Predictions for the national anthem were consistent at approximately 2 minutes, with viewership estimates ranging from 118 million to 130 million. Regarding the most expensive ad, predictions varied: Claude predicted an AI company would spend $8.5 million per 30 seconds; Gemini predicted Anheuser-Busch would spend 2.5 minutes of airtime; ChatGPT and Copilot predicted Apple would spend $14–16 million on a 60-second ad. Betting totals were highly divergent, with Claude predicting $9.2 billion and Gemini forecasting $25 billion in legal bets, while ChatGPT and Copilot estimated between $2.5 billion and $6 billion. The Madden NFL video game also predicted a Seahawks win, though with a 23-20 score. The article notes that AI systems are not infallible and that predictions should be treated as speculative.

**AI Lottery Predictions: Debunking the Myths Behind Kuaile 8, Double Color Ball, and 3D Number Forecasts**
The article examines so-called 'AI lottery predictions' for China's Kuaile 8, Double Color Ball, and 3D lotteries, emphasizing that all such predictions—including those citing AI—are based solely on historical data analysis and have no scientific validity. For the Kuaile 8 draw on February 1, 2026 (Issue 2026033), the AI model suggests focusing on gold number 26, silver number 28, bronze number 39, and key numbers 02, 26, 44, 62, 70. For Double Color Ball, red balls 13, 19, 32 are highlighted as hot numbers in the high-number zone, while blue balls 01 and 10 are considered active. The analysis relies on patterns such as repeating numbers (e.g., 22, 26, 43 in Kuaile 8), hot/cold number tracking (e.g., 02, 26 as hot; 05, 18 as cold), number range distribution (e.g., red balls 20–33 frequently drawn), and consecutive number sequences (e.g., 26–28). However, the article stresses that lottery draws are entirely random, and historical patterns do not predict future outcomes. It warns against common misconceptions like the 'gambler's fallacy'—the belief that hot numbers will continue to appear or cold numbers must 'return'—and cautions against trusting overly complex or 'AI-powered' prediction systems, which may be designed for profit or traffic generation. The recommended mindset is to treat lottery playing as entertainment, not a strategy, and to engage in responsible, rational betting.

**Why Are AI Predictions So Hard in 2026?**
The article explores the growing difficulty of predicting the future of artificial intelligence in 2026, noting that AI advancements are no longer steady or incremental but instead occur in unpredictable leaps. The author observes that AI now exhibits sudden, unexpected skill emergence and behavioral shifts from minor adjustments, while certain problems remain stubbornly unresolved. This erratic progress undermines traditional forecasting models that relied on consistent benchmark improvements and predictable scaling. The article highlights societal concerns about AI's influence on trust, mental health (referencing 'chat psychosis'), electricity consumption, and children's access, all of which reflect broader unease about what lies ahead. Despite AI’s increasing impact on work, learning, and cognition, the lack of a stable trajectory makes long-term predictions increasingly unreliable. The piece concludes that the era of predictable AI development has ended, rendering forecasts more speculative than ever.

Zuckerberg’s forward-looking statement reinforces the expectation that AI infrastructure spending will surge in 2026, supporting Nvidia’s ongoing growth trajectory. **Artificial Intelligence is Redefining the Boundaries of Technology and Art**
Artificial intelligence (AI) is redefining the boundaries between technology and art, as highlighted in a recent article from Sina Finance. The piece outlines several pivotal moments in 2025 where AI reshaped American popular culture. In the film 'Beast Mode,' released in early 2025, actor Adrien Brody won the Academy Award for Best Actor, but controversy erupted when it was revealed that AI was used to enhance his accent to sound more authentically Hungarian—raising debates over authenticity versus technological enhancement. The Academy stated that such digital tools neither add nor subtract from nominations. Film scholar Holly Willis from the University of Southern California argued that film has always been an art of 'fabrication,' from lighting to sound mixing, making AI a natural evolution. In music, the AI-generated band VelvetSundown achieved over one million Spotify streams within weeks, with all creative aspects—including composition, vocals, and virtual personas—produced by AI, sparking debates over legitimacy. Spotify later considered labeling AI-generated content. AI also topped the Billboard Country Digital Song Sales chart with 'WalkMyWalk' and placed a virtual gospel singer, Solomon Ray, in the iTunes Top 100. Legendary producer Timbaland introduced his AI protégé, Tatta Takumi, calling it a 'new direction for art.' In August 2025, Google AI transformed the classic film 'The Wizard of Oz' into an immersive 80-million-dollar Sphere experience in Las Vegas, with characters appearing in 3D around the audience. Professor Dominic Willis of the University of Reading called it not restoration but adaptation. Meanwhile, AI 'digital avatars' are increasingly used in podcasting to record, translate, and interact in real time, though some argue this erodes the intimacy of human connection. In September 2025, digital actress Tilly Noordwijk debuted—created by Dutch artist Irene van der Velden using AI trained on real actors’ performances without consent or compensation—raising ethical concerns about authorship and representation. In December 2025, Disney announced a $1 billion investment in OpenAI and authorized its classic characters to appear on Sora, reversing its earlier lawsuit against Midjourney over unauthorized image replication. The article concludes that AI is now an inseparable part of culture—both collaborator and challenger—forcing society to confront fundamental questions about the nature of art and creativity, with the answer lying not in technology itself, but in how humans choose to use it.

**Meta CEO Zuckerberg: Artificial Intelligence Is the Future of Social Media**
Mark Zuckerberg, CEO of Meta, stated during the company's Q4 2025 earnings call on January 29, 2026, that artificial intelligence (AI) is the future of social media. He explained that social media evolved from text, to photos with smartphone cameras, to video with faster mobile networks, and that the next phase will be driven by AI, enabling more immersive media experiences. Zuckerberg emphasized that current social media relies on recommendation algorithms, but Meta’s future applications will use AI to 'understand' users and deliver personalized content while also generating high-quality, customized content. He previously proposed an AI-driven social media model in 2025, where content and creation would be dynamically mixed, and algorithms would manage vast content libraries. This vision is already being implemented through AI features such as the new 'Vibes' feed, which displays AI-generated short videos. He also predicted that future interactions on social platforms will allow users to create entire worlds or games from a single prompt and share them with friends, and that videos will become interactive. Meta reported Q4 2025 revenue of $59.89 billion (approximately 416.6 billion RMB), a 24% year-over-year increase, and earnings per share (EPS) of $8.88 (approximately 61.8 RMB), surpassing the market consensus of $8.21 (approximately 57.1 RMB).

**As AI Artists Breaking Rush & Cain Walker Rule a Country Chart, Nashville Execs Weigh in: 'It's Incredibly Detrimental'**
As artificial intelligence increasingly infiltrates the music industry, concerns are mounting within the country music community about authenticity and fan trust. According to Billboard's Country Digital Song Sales chart dated November 15, 2025, one-third of the top 10 songs were AI-assisted: 'Walk My Walk' by Breaking Rust (No. 1, selling over 2,000 copies), 'Don't Tread on Me' by Cain Walker (No. 3, over 1,000 copies), and 'Ain't My Problem' (No. 9, slightly under 1,000 copies). These tracks feature bold, defiant lyrics and boisterous vocals, with 'Walk My Walk' having a gospel-stomping feel. While sales remain modest compared to top-selling tracks like Taylor Swift’s 'The Fate of Ophelia' (29,000 copies), AI has already entered radio airplay—Xania Monet became the first known AI artist to chart on the Adult R&B Airplay chart at No. 30. Other AI-assisted acts have also debuted on various Billboard charts. However, terrestrial country radio stations have not added AI songs to their rotations. Country radio consultant Joel Raab notes listeners react negatively to AI voices, and stations prioritize real artists tied to touring and endorsements. Fletcher Foster of F2 Entertainment Group warns that AI songs clog charts and displace real artists who generate revenue through touring, publishing, and brand partnerships. FEMco founder Leslie Fram calls the rise of AI music a 'notable wake-up call' but not an existential threat—yet—emphasizing that while casual listeners may not care, dedicated fans value human imperfection and storytelling. Martina McBride supports the NO FAKES Act, which aims to protect artists’ voices from unauthorized AI replication. Raab and Fram predict that, despite short-term AI popularity, human music with soul and authenticity will ultimately prevail, as true fan loyalty is built on real stories and evolution, not algorithms.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 13, 2025 01:29 AM
Source:[Billboard](https://www.billboard.com/pro/ai-artists-breaking-rust-country-music-chart-reactions/)

**How AI Outperforms Humans in Forecasting the Future**
Every three months, participants in the Metaculus Cup use artificial intelligence to predict geopolitical events in hopes of winning a prize of about $5,000. The platform poses questions such as 'Will Thailand experience a military coup before September 2025?' and 'Will Israel strike the Iranian army again before September 2025?' Experts estimate probabilities rather than simple yes/no answers. For example, Metaculus users correctly predicted the Russian invasion of Ukraine two weeks in advance and assigned a 90 % probability to the U.S. v. Wade case roughly two months before it occurred. When the competition began in June, participants expected AI to outperform humans by 40 % on average, but the Mantic AI system achieved over 80 % accuracy. Prediction experts update their forecasts based on policy changes, allowing them to anticipate how virtual political interventions might affect future outcomes. Broad geopolitical forecasting remains extremely difficult, often requiring days and tens of thousands of dollars for a single question. The Rand Corporation estimates that human experts would need months to produce initial forecasts for all questions and to update them regularly. AI excels in data-rich, well-structured domains like weather or quantitative finance, but for geopolitics it must handle many interrelated factors. Large language models use the same complex information as human forecasters and can simulate human judgment, improving over time by predicting many questions, observing performance, and updating methods on a larger scale than humans can. Machines also have an unfair advantage in the competition: participants earn points not only for accuracy but also for coverage, the number of questions answered, and the frequency of updates. Even less accurate AI can rank highly by continuously updating estimates in response to emerging news—a feat impossible for humans. This unfair advantage helps AI overcome the remaining challenge of producing high‑quality predictions for all questions.
Original language: ar
Publish date: September 21, 2025 11:47 AM
Source:[elnabaa.net](https://www.elnabaa.net/1136072/%D9%83%D9%8A%D9%81-%D9%8A%D8%AA%D9%81%D9%88%D9%82-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B0%D9%83%D8%A7%D8%A1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B5%D8%B7%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%B9%D9%8A-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8%D8%B4%D8%B1-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA%D9%86%D8%A8%D8%A4-%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AA%D9%82%D8%A8%D9%84)

**AI Beats Humans In Predicting Future At International Competition**
A British AI startup, Mantic AI, co‑founded by a former Google DeepMind researcher, finished eighth in the Metaculus Cup, an international forecasting competition that asked participants to predict the likelihood of 60 events over the summer. The competition included high‑profile events such as the public spat between US President Donald Trump and Elon Musk and Kemi Badenoch’s removal from the Conservative Party leadership. Mantic AI’s performance surpassed 80 % of the average score of the top human forecasters, a significant improvement over the 40 % predicted by participants before the contest. Metaculus chief executive Deger Turan called the result 'impressive', while professional forecaster Ben Shindel admitted, 'It's certainly a weird feeling to be outdone by several bots at this point. We've really come a long way here compared with a year ago when the best bot was at something like rank 30.' Co‑founder Toby Shevlane noted that the system’s predictions were more original than most human entrants, arguing that “you could say our system's predictions were more original than most human entrants, because people often cluster around the community average predictions.” Mantic AI uses a mix of machine‑learning models from OpenAI, Google and DeepSeek to assign tasks based on each model’s strengths. Experts suggest that AI’s growing predictive accuracy could signal progress toward Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), with a Google DeepMind paper forecasting AGI as early as 2030.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 20, 2025 12:34 PM
Source:[NDTV](https://www.ndtv.com/science/ai-beats-humans-in-predicting-future-at-international-competition-9312972)

**AI To Predict Future? British Startup Could Soon Overtake Human Forecasting Experts**
Mantic AI, a British artificial‑intelligence startup co‑founded by a former Google DeepMind researcher, finished eighth in the Metaculus Cup, a forecasting competition that asked participants to predict the likelihood of 60 events over the summer. The competition, run by a San Francisco‑based company that serves investment funds and corporations, included events such as the public spat between U.S. President Donald Trump and Elon Musk, Kemi Badenoch’s removal from the Conservative Party leadership, the Samoan general‑election seat distribution, and the number of acres burned by U.S. fires from January to August. Metaculus chief executive Deger Turan said human forecasters are currently "doing better than AI forecasters", while Mantic AI’s co‑founder Toby Shevlane praised the bot’s originality, noting that "You could say our system's predictions were more original than most human entrants, because people often cluster around the community average predictions. The AI system often strongly disagreed. So, AI forecasters could be an antidote to groupthink." Mantic AI breaks each forecasting problem into sub‑tasks and assigns them to a roster of machine‑learning models including OpenAI, Google and DeepSeek. Although the bot’s performance lagged behind the best human forecasters, experts predict it could reach parity or exceed human performance by 2029. Philip Tetlock, co‑author of Superforecasting, noted that expert humans still outperform top AI bots as of now.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 20, 2025 11:02 AM

**AI Models Learn to Predict the Future: Will They Replace Expert Analysts?**
The article reports that artificial‑intelligence models are becoming increasingly accurate in predicting geopolitical events in the Metaculus forecasting contest, which offers a prize of about $5,000 and attracts roughly 600 participants. In June, the best human forecaster was expected to score about 40 % of the average of top forecasters; the AI developed by Mantic achieved more than 80 % of that average, placing eighth among 549 participants. Mantic’s CEO Toby Shivein described the results as ‘просто невероятны’. The piece is largely factual, with occasional praise for AI, and does not exhibit overt bias.

**AI Models Learn to Predict the Future: Will They Replace Analyst Experts**
The article reports that the Metaculus forecasting competition, which offers a prize pool of about $5,000, has recently begun to include artificial‑intelligence (AI) models in its contests.  In the latest round, an AI developed by the British startup Mantic, led by CEO Toby Shivein, achieved a score of over 80 %—well above the 40 % average that participants expected for the best bot—placing it eighth among 549 entrants.  The competition featured 60 geopolitical questions, such as whether a military coup will occur in Thailand by September 2025 or whether Israel will strike Iranian military targets by the same deadline.  The article cites RAND analyst Anthony Vassallo, who says forecasts help “prevent surprises and aid decision‑makers,” and Nathan Mazzotti, who notes that forecasting is ubiquitous in government agencies.  Vassallo argues that the AI’s “unfair advantage” of continuously updating predictions is actually beneficial because it yields a large volume of high‑quality forecasts.  The piece also mentions that AI models can learn from millions of predictions, citing LightningRod’s training on 100 000 questions.  Finally, it notes that Albania appointed an AI model, Diella, as a virtual minister of public procurement, marking the first time a government position has been filled by a non‑human.  The article is largely factual and includes direct quotes, such as Shivein’s description of the AI’s results as ‘simply incredible’ and Vassallo’s statement that he “doesn’t need it to reach ‘super‑forecasting’ level; he just needs it to be as good as the crowd.’

**AI Is Learning to Predict the Future -- And Beating Humans at It**
Metaculus runs a quarterly forecasting cup in which participants predict geopolitical events for a prize pot of about $5,000. The platform poses questions such as 'Will Thailand experience a military coup before September 2025?' and 'Will Israel strike the Iranian military again before September 2025?'. Forecasters estimate probabilities weeks to months in advance, often with remarkable accuracy. For instance, users correctly predicted the date of the Russian invasion of Ukraine two weeks in advance, and assigned a 90 percent chance to Roe v. Wade being overturned almost two months before the decision.
